Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Autologous Osteoblastic Cell Therapy versus Bone Marrow Aspirate Concentrate in Pre-collapse Osteonecrosis of the Femoral Head

Participants.evidence: 67 patients with Stage I or II ONFH, excluding those with traumatic ONFH, hemoglobinopathies, or positive serology for hepatitis B, C, or HIV

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to core decompression with either BMAC (n = 26) or osteoblastic cell therapy (n = 30)

Objective.evidence: assessed whether autologous osteoblastic cell therapy could reduce progression to subchondral fracture and improve pain compared to bone marrow aspirate concentrate

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the absence of progression to subchondral fracture (ARCO stage III or higher) and a clinically important pain improvement over 36 months

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomly assigned to core decompression with either BMAC (n = 26) or osteoblastic cell therapy (n = 30)

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted as-treated for efficacy and intention-to-treat for adverse events

Result_Outcome.evidence: no significant differences were found in progression to fracture (46% BMAC vs. 22% osteoblastic cells; hazard ratio, 0.47 [95% CI 0.17 to 1.31]; p = 0.15)

Harms.evidence: No differences were observed in THA rates (15% osteoblastic cells vs. 35% BMAC; p = 0.09) or adverse events
